title: Threat Modeling

description.short: Identify and prioritize security threats before building
description.medium: Systematic approach to identifying, quantifying, and addressing security threats during the planning phase - cheaper to fix in design than production
description.full: Threat modeling is a structured process for identifying potential security threats, understanding their likelihood and impact, and planning mitigations before writing code. Using frameworks like STRIDE, you can systematically think about what could go wrong and design defenses accordingly. This prevents building vulnerable systems and is far cheaper than fixing security issues in production.

why_it_matters: Catches security issues before they're built into the system
Cheaper to fix vulnerabilities in design than production (10-100x cost difference)
Helps prioritize security work based on actual risk
Creates shared security understanding across team
Required by most compliance frameworks (SOC2, HIPAA, etc.)

objectives: Understand what threat modeling is and why it matters
Identify 3 critical threats to your system
Know when you absolutely must do this
key_takeaways: List 3 things an attacker could do to your system
For each threat, identify one simple mitigation
Don't need formal frameworks for MVP - just think it through
15 minutes of threat modeling can prevent catastrophic vulnerabilities

objectives: Use STRIDE framework for systematic analysis
Integrate threat modeling into design process
key_takeaways: STRIDE covers 6 threat categories: Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information Disclosure, Denial of Service, Elevation of Privilege
Risk = Likelihood Ã— Impact helps prioritization
Threat modeling is collaborative, not solo work
Update threat model when system changes

objectives: Apply DREAD scoring for quantitative risk assessment
Train teams on threat modeling practices
key_takeaways: Quantitative scoring enables business risk decisions
Compliance frameworks require documented threat models
Threat models evolve as systems change
Security champions can facilitate threat modeling sessions

frameworks_and_concepts: STRIDE (Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information Disclosure, DoS, Elevation of Privilege)
DREAD (Damage, Reproducibility, Exploitability, Affected Users, Discoverability)
compliance_relevance: SOC 2 Type II (required for security criteria)
HIPAA (required as part of security risk assessment)
ISO 27001 (part of information security risk management)

estimated_time_to_implement.deep_water: 2-5 days for enterprise threat modeling program

common_mistakes: Skipping threat modeling for apps handling sensitive data
Doing threat modeling after code is written
Threat modeling as solo activity instead of team exercise
Never revisiting threat model as system evolves
Getting paralyzed by trying to identify every possible threat
Not documenting identified threats and mitigations
success_metrics: Security vulnerabilities caught in design review
Team can articulate top 3-5 system threats
Mitigations in place for critical threats
Threat model updated when architecture changes
when_to_prioritize: Building apps that handle sensitive data
After security incident or vulnerability discovery
when_to_deprioritize: Proof of concepts without real data
Internal tools with no sensitive data
Extremely tight deadlines (but plan to revisit)

domain_variations.web-apps: Focus on OWASP Top 10 threats (SQLi, XSS, CSRF)
domain_variations.mobile-apps: Consider platform security models, device security, offline data
domain_variations.ml-systems: Include model poisoning, adversarial inputs, data privacy
domain_variations.iot: Physical access and hardware tampering threats
domain_variations.healthcare: HIPAA-specific threats to PHI (Protected Health Information)
domain_variations.fintech: Financial fraud and transaction integrity threats
